questions.text: Practical Approach to Lung health (PAL) includes all except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Carcinoma of the lung, commonly referred to as lung cancer, is not typically included in the Practical Approach to Lung Health (PAL) strategy.
  • The Practical Approach to Lung Health (PAL) strategyis a comprehensive approach developed by the World Health Organization (WHO) to address common respiratory conditions effectively.
  • It aims to provide practical guidance for healthcare providers in managing lung diseases at the primary healthcare level.
  • Lung cancer diagnosis and treatment often require specialized interventions beyond the scope of primary healthcare, such as advanced imaging, biopsy, oncology consultations, and specialized treatments like surgery, chemotherapy, or radiotherapy.

Diseases Targeted by PAL:

  • Acute respiratory infections(e.g., pneumonia, bronchitis)
  • Chronic respiratory diseases(e.g., asthma, COPD) (Option B, C ruled out)
  • Tuberculosis (TB)and other infectious lung diseases (Option A ruled out)
  • Occupational lung diseases(e.g., silicosis)

questions.text: Which of the following colour is assigned to Kit 4 available in STI/RTI clinics under NACP?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Kit 4 of the STI/RTI color coded kits is coded bluein color, and is used for Genital ulcer disease management (e.g., syphilis, chancroid).
  • Under the National AIDS Control Programme (NACP), STI/RTI (Sexually Transmitted Infections/Reproductive Tract Infections) clinics provide diagnostic and treatment services for sexually transmitted infections.
  • These clinics often distribute kits for testing and diagnosing STIs/RTIs.

RTI/STI color coded kits:

questions.text: Case detection in STDs is done by all except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Notification typically refers to informing public health authorities or relevant stakeholders about cases of infectious diseases, including STDs.
  • While notification is an essential component of disease surveillance and control, it is not a method specifically used for case detection in STDs.
  • Instead, notification occurs after cases have been detected through screening, contact tracing, or cluster testing, and it involves reporting cases to public health agencies for monitoring and intervention.

Incorrect options::

Screening (Option A):

  • Screening involves testing individuals for STDs, even if they do not have symptoms.
  • This method is used to identify asymptomatic individuals who may be infected with STDs and may be unknowingly transmitting the infection to others.
  • Screening is an essential tool for early detection and prevention of STD transmission.

Contact tracing (Option B):

  • Contact tracing involves identifying and notifying individuals who may have been exposed to an STD through sexual contact with an infected person.
  • Health authorities or healthcare providers interview individuals diagnosed with an STD to obtain information about their sexual partners, and then notify and offer testing and treatment to these partners.
  • Contact tracing helps break the chain of STD transmission by identifying and treating individuals who may be infected but unaware of their status.

Cluster testing (Option C):

  • Cluster testing, also known as partner notification testing or index partner testing, involves testing the sexual partners of individuals diagnosed with an STD.
  • When an individual tests positive for an STD, their sexual partners are notified and encouraged to get tested for the same infection.
  • Cluster testing helps identify additional cases of STDs within sexual networks and facilitates prompt treatment to prevent further transmission.

questions.text: The method of case detection for STDs in which a person names the persons moving in the same socio-sexual environment is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Cluster testing, also known as Partner notification testing orIndex partner testing, involves identifying and testing individuals who have been named by an index patient as sexual contacts or partners.
  • When someone is diagnosed with an STD, they are asked to provide information about their recent sexual partners.
  • These named partners are then contacted and offered testing for the same STD. Cluster testing helps identify additional cases of STDs within sexual networks and facilitates prompt treatment to prevent further transmission.

Incorrect Options:

Contact tracing (Option B):

  • Contact tracing involves identifying and notifying individuals who may have been exposed to an STD through sexual contact with an infected person.
  • Contact tracing typically relies on interviewing individuals diagnosed with an STD to obtain information about their sexual partners.
  • However, contact tracing does not necessarily involve the index patient specifically naming individuals in the same socio-sexual environment. Instead, it focuses on identifying and notifying all potential sexual contacts.

High-risk screening (Option C):

  • High-risk screening involves targeting individuals who are at increased risk of acquiring STDs based on specific criteria, such as sexual behaviour, demographic factors, or clinical indicators.
  • While high-risk screening may involve testing individuals who are part of the same socio-sexual environment as the index patient, it does not rely on the index patient specifically naming these individuals.
  • Instead, screening criteria are used to identify individuals who may benefit from STD testing based on their risk factors.

Selective screening (Option D):

  • Selective screening refers to targeting specific populations or groups for STD testing based on predetermined criteria, such as age, gender, sexual orientation, or geographic location.
  • Similar to high-risk screening, selective screening does not rely on the index patient naming individuals in the same socio-sexual environment.
  • Instead, screening criteria are used to identify populations at increased risk of STDs who may benefit from testing.

Key Takeaways:

  • Cluster testing relies on index patient naming partnersin their socio-sexual network.
  • Distinct from contact tracing (broader notification) or screening (risk-based criteria).

questions.text: Obesity in India suggests BMI more than:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A BMI of 25 or higher is typically used to define obesity in India and many other countries.

In India, obesity is typically defined using the Body Mass Index (BMI), which is calculated by dividing a person's weight in kilograms by the square of their height in meters.

BMI = weight in kg / (height in meters) ²

questions.text: Cut off for Waist circumference considered as unhealthy for Indian male is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A waist circumference of 90cm or higher is commonly used to define Abdominal obesity and is considered unhealthy for Indian males. This cutoff point reflects an increased risk of metabolic syndrome and related health conditions.

A waist circumference of 80cm or higher is commonly considered unhealthy for Indian females.

  • Waist circumference is an important indicator of abdominal obesity and is commonly used as a measure of central adiposity.
  • It is closely associated with an increased risk of metabolic syndrome, type 2 diabetes, cardiovascular disease, and other health conditions.
  • The cutoff points for waist circumference to define abdominal obesity vary by population and ethnicity.
  • In India, the cutoff points for waist circumference considered unhealthy for males are generally lower compared to Western populations due to differences in body

questions.text: Which of the following does not belong to Step 3 procedure under the WHO Step-wise approach for surveillance (STEPS) of Non-Communicable Disease risk factors?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The WHO Stepwise approach for surveillance of non-communicable disease (NCD) risk factors, often referred to as STEPS, is a comprehensive framework for collecting, analyzing, and disseminating data on the major risk factors for NCDs. The STEPS framework consists of three steps, each focusing on different aspects of NCD risk factors:

  • Step 1: Involves collecting demographic and behavioral information through interviews. This step typically includes questions about tobacco use, alcohol consumption, dietary habits, and physical activity levels.
  • Step 2: Involves taking physical measurements, such as height, weight, waist circumference, and biochemical measurements, including blood glucose levels for diabetes and Blood pressure.
  • Step 3: Involves taking additional biochemical measurements and assessing additional risk factors, such as diabetes and hypertension. This step typically includes measuring fasting blood sugar (FBS), urine sugar, and additional lipid profile measurements (Option B, C, D ruled out).

questions.text: Blindness caused by opacities in the lens comes under:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Type II blindness is associated with Opacities in the lens of the eye, which can lead to impaired vision or blindness.

These opacities often result from conditions such as Cataracts, where the normally clear lens becomes cloudy or opaque, obstructing the passage of light and affecting vision.

Incorrect options:

Type I (Option A): Typically refers to blindness caused by conditions affecting the Optic nerve, Retina, or other structures involved in vision perception, such as Glaucoma or Retinal detachment.

Type III (Option C): There is no widely recognised classification of blindness referred to as "Type III."

Type IV (Option D): Similarly, there is no widely recognised classification of blindness referred to as "Type IV."

choices.text: 10% relative reduction in harmful use of alcohol
30% relative reduction in mean population intake of sodium
10% relative reduction in prevalence of insufficient physical activity
10% relative reduction in use of trans-fat for cooking

questions.text: The WHO has formulated a Global Action Plan for the prevention and control of non-communicable diseases. Which of the following is not a voluntary global target under this initiative?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

While reducing trans-fat consumption is an important public health goal due to its association with cardiovascular diseases, it is not specifically listed as one of the voluntary global targets in the plan.

The Global Action Plan (GAP) for NCDs, developed by the WHO, is a strategic framework to reduce the global burden of non-communicable diseases (NCDs), which are the leading cause of death worldwide.

The plan focuses on prevention, early detection, treatment, and policy interventions to curb the rise of NCDs, particularly in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs).

The plan prioritizes four major disease groups, responsible for 80% of NCD-related deaths:

  1. Cardiovascular diseases (e.g., heart attacks, strokes)
  2. Cancers
  3. Chronic respiratory diseases (e.g., COPD, asthma)
  4. Diabetes

Additionally, it addresses shared risk factors:

  • Mental health disorders
  • Obesity
  • Liver and kidney diseases

Objectives:

  1. Strengthen Political Commitment
    • Advocate for NCDs as a public health priority in national policies.
  2. Reduce Modifiable Risk Factors
    • Target tobacco use, unhealthy diets, physical inactivity, and harmful alcohol use.
  3. Improve Healthcare Systems
    • Enhance early detection, treatment, and access to essential medicines.
  4. Strengthen Surveillance & Research
    • Monitor NCD trends and risk factors via systems like the WHO STEPwise Approach.
  5. Promote Multisectoral Collaboration
    • Engage sectors beyond health (e.g., agriculture, education, urban planning).
  6. Monitor Progress
    • Track indicators like premature NCD mortality.

Targets:

  1. Reduce premature mortality from NCDs: A 25% relative reduction by 2025, extended to a one-third (33.3%) reduction by 2030, in premature mortality from cardiovascular diseases, cancer, diabetes, or chronic respiratory diseases.
  2. Reduce harmful use of alcohol: At least a 10% relative reduction (Option A ruled out).
  3. Reduce physical inactivity: A 10% relative reduction by 2025, extended to a 15% reduction by 2030 (Option C ruled out).
  4. Reduce mean population intake of salt/sodium: A 30% relative reduction(Option B ruled out).
  5. Reduce prevalence of current tobacco use: A 30% relative reduction in persons aged 15+ years.
  6. Reduce or contain the prevalence of raised blood pressure: A 25% relative reduction or containment, according to national circumstances.
  7. Halt the rise in diabetes and obesity.
  8. Increase drug therapy and counselling for heart attacks and strokes: At least 50% of eligible people receive drug therapy and counselling.
  9. Improve availability of affordable basic technologies and essential medicines: An 80% availability of required technologies and essential medicines, including generics, in both public and private facilities.

questions.text: Project MONICA is related to:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Project MONICA (Monitoring of Trends and Determinants in Cardiovascular Disease) is indeed related to cardiovascular diseases.
  • Project MONICA primarily focuses on monitoring trends and determinants in cardiovascular diseases.
  • It involves extensive research and surveillance to understand the epidemiology, risk factors, and trends related to heart disease and stroke.
  • The project aims to gather data from different populations to develop strategies for the prevention and control of cardiovascular diseases.

choices.text: Lipid metabolism with fall in levels of HDL

questions.text: Which of the following is a mechanism for the relation between Smoking and CHD?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Smoking exerts its detrimental effects on cardiovascular health through multiple mechanisms, including carbon monoxide-induced atherogenesis, nicotine stimulation of adrenergic drive, and alterations in lipid metabolism leading to reduced HDL cholesterol levels.

Carbon monoxide induced Atherogenesis:

  • Smoking exposes individuals to carbon monoxide (CO), a toxic gas present in tobacco smoke.
  • Carbon monoxide can lead to the formation of atheromas (plaques) in the arteries by promoting the oxidation of low-density lipoproteins (LDL) and impairing the function of endothelial cells lining the blood vessels.
  • This process contributes to the development of atherosclerosis, a major risk factor for coronary heart disease (CHD).

Nicotine stimulation of adrenergic drive: 

  • Nicotine, the addictive component of tobacco, stimulates the release of catecholamines (e.g., adrenaline) from the adrenal glands and sympathetic nerve terminals.
  • Increased sympathetic activity can lead to elevated heart rate, blood pressure, and myocardial oxygen demand, thereby increasing the risk of CHD and other cardiovascular events.

Lipid metabolism with fall in levels of HDL:

  • Smoking can adversely affect lipid metabolism, leading to alterations in the levels of various lipid components in the blood.
  • It is associated with decreased levels of high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol, commonly known as "good" cholesterol, which plays a protective role in cardiovascular health.
  • Lower levels of HDL cholesterol are associated with an increased risk of CHD.

choices.text: Reduction of salt intake to less than 10 g per day
Consumption of saturated fats limited to less than 10% of the total energy intake
Reduction of total fat intake to less than 5% of total energy intake
Dietary cholesterol increased to above 100mg/1000 kcal energy intake

questions.text: A 45-year-old obese woman enquires about ways she can reduce her risk of coronary artery disease. Which of the following dietary modifications would you suggest?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Out of the given options, Consumption of saturated fats limited to less than 10% of the total energy intakeis the recommended dietary modification to reduce the risk of coronary artery disease.
  • Saturated fats, found primarily in animal products such as red meat, butter, cheese, and full-fat dairy, can increase levels of LDL cholesterol ("bad" cholesterol) in the blood, which is a major risk factor for CAD.
  • Limiting saturated fat intake to less than 10% of total energy intake helps lower LDL cholesterol levels and reduce the risk of CAD.

Incorrect options:

Reduction of salt intake to less than 10 g per day (Option A): Excessive salt intake is associated with high blood pressure, which is a risk factor for CAD, but salt reduction alone may not sufficiently address other dietary factors contributing to CAD risk.

Reduction of total fat intake to less than 5% of total energy intake (Option C): While reducing overall fat intake can be beneficial for weight management and overall health, excessively low-fat diets (less than 15-20% of total energy intake) may not provide sufficient essential fatty acids and fat-soluble vitamins. Moreover, focusing solely on total fat intake may overlook the importance of differentiating between types of fats, such as saturated fats, which have a more significant impact on CAD risk.

Dietary cholesterol increased to above 100mg/1000 kcal energy intake (Option D): This recommendation contradicts current dietary guidelines, which advise limiting dietary cholesterol intake to reduce the risk of CAD. High intake of dietary cholesterol, particularly from sources like egg yolks and organ meats, can contribute to elevated levels of LDL cholesterol and increase the risk of CAD.

questions.text: Which of the following studies is not related to coronary heart disease?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Clinical Antipsychotic Trials of Intervention Effectiveness (CATIE) trial is not related to coronary heart disease. Instead, it is a landmark study comparing the effectiveness of antipsychotic medications in the treatment of schizophrenia.

The CATIE trial aimed to determine the efficacy, tolerability, and side effects of different antipsychotic drugs in patients with schizophrenia.

Incorrect options:

Stanford 3 Community Study (Option A): This study investigated the relationship between lifestyle factors, including diet and physical activity, and the risk of coronary heart disease (CHD) in three communities in California. It aimed to identify factors associated with CHD incidence and mortality.

Framingham Study (Option B):

  • The Framingham Heart Study is a well-known longitudinal cohort study initiated in 1948 in Framingham, Massachusetts.
  • It has provided extensive insights into the epidemiology and risk factors of cardiovascular diseases, including coronary heart disease.
  • The study has contributed significantly to understanding the roles of various factors such as hypertension, cholesterol levels, smoking, diabetes, and obesity in the development of CHD.

MRFIT (Option D):

  • The Multiple Risk Factor Intervention Trial (MRFIT) was a large randomisedcontrolled trial conducted in the 1970s to investigate the effects of various interventions aimed at reducing cardiovascular risk factors on the incidence of coronary heart disease and mortality.
  • The study targeted men at high risk of cardiovascular disease and assessed the impact of interventions such as smoking cessation, cholesterol reduction, and blood pressure control on CHD outcomes.

choices.text: BP falls steadily in the elderly
Hypertensive children become hypotensive as they grow
BP of hypotensive children tends to remain low in adult life

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding tracking of blood pressure?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

BP increases with age due to:

  • Arterial stiffening (reduced elasticity of blood vessels)
  • Increased peripheral vascular resistance
  • Atherosclerotic changes with aging
  • Supported by longitudinal studies showing systolic BP rises ~0.6 mmHg/year after age 30

Incorrect Options:

BP falls steadily in the elderly (Option B): Incorrect. While diastolic BP may plateau/decrease after age 60, systolic BP continues rising.

Hypertensive children become hypotensive as they grow (Option C): Incorrect. BP tracking shows hypertensive children tend to remain hypertensive ("tracking phenomenon").

BP of hypotensive children tends to remain low in adult life (Option D): Partially true but less significant than option A. BP tracking is stronger for high-normal values.

questions.text: Which of the following is a minor criterion for the diagnosis of Rheumatic fever in a low-risk population?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Rheumatic fever is diagnosed based on the Jones criteria, which include major and minor criteria. In low-risk populations,the diagnosis of Rheumatic fever requires the presence of either Two major criteria or one major criterion plus two minor criteria, along with evidence of recent Streptococcal infection.
  • Polyarthralgia, which refers to pain in multiple joints, is a minor criterion for the diagnosis of rheumatic fever, in Low-risk population.
  • It is important to note that polyarthralgia alone does not fulfil the criteria for diagnosis; it must be accompanied by other criteria or evidence of recent streptococcal infection.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy with rheumatic fever developed carditis, which subsequently healed in a couple of weeks. How long will you administer benzathine penicillin G for secondary prophylaxis to him?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Secondary prophylaxis with benzathine penicillin G is crucial for preventing recurrent episodes of rheumatic fever and subsequent Rheumatic heart disease.
  • The duration of secondary prophylaxis depends on the patient's age, the severity of the initial rheumatic fever episode, and the presence of residual heart disease.
  • In general, it is recommended to continue secondary prophylaxis until at least 26 years of age or for a minimum of 10 years after the last episode of rheumatic fever, whichever is longer (Option A, B, D ruled out).

questions.text: Which of the following is not a protective factor for diabetes mellitus?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Saturated fats have been linked to an increased risk of type 2 diabetes and cardiovascular disease. High intake of saturated fats, commonly found in red meat, full-fat dairy products, and certain processed foods, can impair insulin sensitivity, promote inflammation, and contribute to weight gain, all of which are risk factors for diabetes mellitus.

Incorrect options:

Intake of PUFAs (Polyunsaturated Fatty Acids) (Option A):

  • Polyunsaturated fats, including omega-3and omega-6 fatty acids, have been associated with a reduced risk of developing type 2 diabetes.
  • Foods rich in PUFAs, such as fatty fish (e.g., salmon, mackerel, sardines), nuts, and seeds, have shown beneficial effects on insulin sensitivity and glucose metabolism.

Intake of non-starch polysaccharides (option B):

  • Non-starchpolysaccharides, also known as dietary fibre, are found in plant-based foods such as whole grains, fruits, vegetables, legumes, and nuts.
  • High intake of dietary fibre has been consistently linked to a reduced risk of type 2 diabetes. Fibrehelps regulate blood sugar levels, improves insulin sensitivity, and promotes satiety, which can aid in weight management.

Exclusive breastfeeding (Option C):

  • Exclusive breastfeeding during infancy has been associated with a lower risk of developing type 2 diabetes later in life for both the mother and the child.
  • Breastfeeding provides essential nutrients to the infant and may contribute to healthy metabolic programming, reducing the likelihood of obesity and insulin resistance in adulthood.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms is least likely to be associated with malignancies?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Among the options provided, HPV 6 and 11 are least likely to be associated with malignancies.
  • HPV types 6 and 11 are considered low-risk types of human papillomavirus (HPV).
  • While they can cause genital warts (condyloma acuminata) and benign lesions, they are not strongly associated with malignancies.
  • High-risk HPV types, particularly HPV 16 and 18, are strongly linked to the development of cervical, anal, vulvar, vaginal, penile, and oropharyngeal cancers.

Incorrect options:

Cytomegalovirus (CMV) (Option A): CMV infection has been associated with certain malignancies, particularly in immunocompromised individuals such as transplant recipients and people living with HIV/AIDS. It is linked to cancers such as Lymphomas and certain solid tumors.

Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) (Option B): EBV is strongly associated with several malignancies, including Burkitt lymphoma, Hodgkin lymphoma, Nasopharyngeal carcinoma, and some Gastric cancers. It is considered an oncogenic virus due to its ability to transform infected cells and promote tumor formation.

Schistosoma (Option D): Chronic infection with Schistosoma parasites (e.g., Schistosoma haematobium, Schistosoma mansoni) is associated with an increased risk of developing bladder cancer (in the case of S. haematobium) and colorectal cancer (in the case of S. mansoni). The parasites' eggs can induce chronic inflammation and promote carcinogenesis in affected tissues.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a primary method of prevention of carcinoma in the population?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Screening refers to the early detection of a disease or condition in asymptomatic individuals before symptoms develop.
  • While screening is crucial for the early detection and treatment of certain cancers, such as breast, cervical, and colorectal cancer, it is not considered a primary method of prevention.
  • Screening helps identify individuals at risk or with early-stage disease, but it does not prevent the occurrence of cancer itself.

Incorrect options:

Restricting the use of tobacco (Option B):

  • Tobacco use, including smoking cigarettes and using smokeless tobacco products, is a well-established risk factor for various types of cancer, including lung, mouth, throat, esophageal, and pancreatic cancer.
  • Therefore, restricting the use of tobacco products through tobacco control policies, public health campaigns, and smoking cessation programs is a primary method of preventing cancer by reducing exposure to carcinogens.

Immunisation (Option C): Immunisation, particularly through vaccination against infectious agents known to cause cancer, is a primary method of cancer prevention. For example, vaccination against human papillomavirus (HPV) can prevent HPV-related cervical, anal, vulvar, vaginal, penile, and oropharyngeal cancers. Similarly, vaccination against hepatitis B virus (HBV) can reduce the risk of liver cancer.

Avoiding alcohol (Option D): Alcohol consumption is associated with an increased risk of developing several types of cancer, including cancers of the mouth, throat, esophagus, liver, breast, and colorectal region. Therefore, avoiding or limiting alcohol consumption is considered a primary method of cancer prevention.

choices.text: Ca oral cavity and Ca breast

questions.text: According to Globocan 2022 India, which of the following are the most common malignancies among men and women, respectively?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

According to Globocan 2020 data for India, the most common malignancies among men and women, respectively are:

Ca oral cavity (including lip and pharynx) for men: Oral cancer, which includes cancers of the lips, tongue, mouth, and throat, is one of the leading cancers among men in India. This can be attributed to various factors, including tobacco and alcohol consumption, betel quid chewing, and poor oral hygiene.

Ca breast for women: Breast cancer is the most common cancer among women in India. It accounts for a significant proportion of cancer cases and cancer-related deaths among women worldwide. Risk factors for breast cancer include genetic predisposition, hormonal factors, lifestyle factors, and environmental exposures.

choices.text: A woman who attained menarche at 9 years of age
A woman who has never breastfed in her lifetime
A woman who attained menopause at 56 years of age
A woman who had her first full-term pregnancy at 26 years of age

questions.text: Which of the following women is not at an increased risk of developing breast cancer in future?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Having a first full-term pregnancy at a younger age (usually before 30) is associated with a lower risk of breast cancer.
  • Pregnancy induces changes in breast tissue that may reduce the risk of developing breast cancer later in life. Therefore, this option represents a protective factor against breast cancer.
  • Breast cancer risk factors can be categorised into Non-modifiable and Modifiable factors:

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman is at increased risk of breast cancer as she is on hormone replacement therapy. Which of the following is the most sensitive method of screening for this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Mammography is considered the most sensitive method for screening for breast cancer, especially in high-risk individuals such as women on hormone replacement therapy.
  • Mammography is the gold standard for breast cancer screening in women, particularly those aged 50 and older.
  • It uses low-dose X-rays to detect breast abnormalities, including tumors or calcifications, before they can be felt.
  • Mammography has been shown to reduce breast cancer mortality by detecting cancers at an early stage when treatment is more effective.

Incorrect options:

Self breast examination (SBE) (Option A): SBE involves women examining their breasts regularly to detect any changes or abnormalities. While SBE can empower women to become familiar with their breast tissue and detect changes, it has limitations in terms of sensitivity and specificity. Studies have shown that SBE alone is not as effective as mammography in detecting breast cancer at an early stage.

Clinical breast examination (CBE) (Option B): CBE involves a healthcare provider examining the breasts for any abnormalities or signs of breast cancer. While CBE can complement mammography and provide additional information, it is not as sensitive as mammography for detecting early-stage breast cancer.

Ultrasound (USG) breast (Option C): Breast ultrasound may be used as a supplemental imaging modality in certain cases, such as evaluating breast lumps detected on mammography or clinical examination. However, it is not routinely used as a primary screening tool for breast cancer, especially in asymptomatic individuals.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best level of prevention of breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Early diagnosis and treatmentfocus on detecting breast cancer at an early stage when it is most treatable and improving outcomes through prompt and effective interventions.
  • This level of prevention includes breast cancer screening programsaimed at detecting cancer in asymptomatic individuals (e.g., mammography, clinical breast examination) and encouraging women to seek medical attention promptly if they notice any breast changes or symptoms (e.g., breast lumps, nipple discharge, skin changes).
  • Early diagnosis allows for timely initiation of appropriate treatment modalities, such as surgery, chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and targeted therapies, which can improve survival rates and quality of life.
  • Early diagnosis and treatment represent the best level of prevention for breast cancer, as it offers the greatest opportunity for reducing morbidity and mortality associated with the disease.

Breast cancer prevention strategies can be categorised into three levels: primary prevention, secondary prevention, and tertiary prevention:

Incorrect options:

Specific protection (Option A):

  • Specific protection refers to measures taken to prevent the occurrence of a disease in individuals who are not yet affected.
  • In the context of breast cancer, specific protection would include interventions aimed at reducing risk factors associated with breast cancer development, such as lifestyle modifications (e.g., maintaining a healthy weight, regular physical activity, limiting alcohol consumption), chemoprevention (e.g., using medications like tamoxifen or aromatase inhibitors in high-risk women), and prophylactic surgery (e.g., bilateral mastectomy in women with BRCA mutations).
  • While these measures are effective inreducing the risk of developing breast cancer, they cannot be implemented on a community level.

Disability limitation (Option C): Disability limitation involves interventions aimed at minimising the impact of a disease or condition on individuals who already have the condition. While disability limitation strategies are important for improving outcomes and quality of life for individuals living with breast cancer (e.g., rehabilitation programs, supportive care services), they are not considered the primary focus of breast cancer prevention efforts.

Rehabilitation (Option D): Rehabilitation focuses on restoring function and quality of life for individuals who have undergone treatment for breast cancer or are living with the consequences of the disease. While rehabilitation services are crucial components of comprehensive cancer care, they primarily address the needs of individuals after they have been diagnosed and treated for breast cancer, rather than preventing the occurrence of the disease.

In summary, early diagnosis and treatment represent the best level of prevention for breast cancer, as it emphasizes the importance of detecting the disease early and initiating timely and appropriate interventions to improve outcomes and reduce mortality.

questions.text: Which of the following indices of obesity is obtained by dividing weight in kg by square of height in metres?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Quetelet's index, also known as the Body Mass Index (BMI), is obtained by dividing the weight in kilograms by the square of height in meters.
  • It is one of the most commonly used indices to assess body composition and classify individuals into different categories of weight status, such as underweight, normal weight, overweight, and obesity.
  • BMI is recommended by various health organizations and is used in clinical practice, research, and public health settings.

Options A, B, C ruled out.

choices.text: The cutoff for normal waist circumference in Indian women is 90 cm
It is measured at the midpoint between the lower border of the rib cage and the iliac crest
It is an approximate index of intra-abdominal and total body fat
It is an indicator of the risk of chronic diseases

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding waist circumference?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The cutoff for normal waist circumference in Indian women is typically lower than 90 cm.

According to WHO, there is an increased of metabolic complications for a waist circumferance > 102 cm in men, and > 88 cm in women

Explanation to why other options are not correct:

It is measured at the midpoint between the lower border of the rib cage and the iliac crest (Option B): It is measured at a horizontal level around the abdomen, typically at the midpoint between the lower border of the rib cage and the iliac crest (the top of the pelvic bone). Measurement should be taken at the end of a normal expiration, with the tape measure snug but not compressing the skin.

It is an approximate index of intra-abdominal and total body fat (Option C):

  • Waist circumference is considered an approximate index of intra-abdominal fat (visceral fat) and total body fat.
  • Excess intra-abdominal fat is associated with an increased risk of various chronic diseases, including type 2 diabetes, cardiovascular disease, and metabolic syndrome.
  • Waist circumference measurement provides valuable information about the distribution of body fat, complementing other measures such as body mass index (BMI).

It is an indicator of the risk of chronic diseases (Option D):

  • Waist circumference is widely recognized as an indicator of the risk of chronic diseases, particularly those related to abdominal obesity.
  • Individuals with a larger waist circumference, indicative of excess abdominal fat, are at higher risk of developing conditions such as type 2 diabetes, hypertension, dyslipidemia, and cardiovascular disease.
  • Abdominal obesity is often considered a stronger predictor of health risks than overall obesity measured by BMI.

questions.text: According to the WHO, what is the cut-off for visual acuity for blindness?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

According to the World Health Organization (WHO), blindness is defined as 'Visual acuity less than 3/60 in the better eye with the best possible correction, or a visual field of less than 10 degrees from the point of fixation' (Option A, C, D ruled out).

This means that a person with a visual acuity of 3/60 or worse is considered functionally blind.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of injury related death?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Road traffic accidents are the leading cause of injury-related deaths globally.
  • RTAs involve accidents that occur on roads, highways, and streets involving vehicles such as cars, motorcycles, bicycles, and pedestrians. These accidents often result in severe injuries and fatalities due to the high speeds and forces involved.
  • Factors contributing to RTAs include speeding, impaired driving (due to alcohol or drugs), distracted driving (e.g., texting while driving), and poor road infrastructure.
  • India accounts for around 10 % of Global RTAs, with an incidence of 36,084 documented cases in 2024.

Explanation to why other options are not correct:

Interpersonal Violence (Option A): Interpersonal violence, including assaults, homicides, and domestic violence, is a concerning issue worldwide. While interpersonal violence can result in fatalities, its overall contribution to injury-related deaths is lower compared to road traffic accidents.

Falls (Option B): Falls are a significant cause of injury-related deaths, especially among the elderly population. Falls can occur due to various reasons such as slipping on wet surfaces, tripping over objects, or falling from heights. While falls contribute significantly to

Suicide (Option D): Suicide is another important cause of injury-related deaths, particularly among certain age groups and populations with mental health issues. However, it accounts for a smaller proportion of injury-related deaths compared to road traffic accidents.

choices.text: A person who sheds pathogens during incubation period
Carrier who acquired pathogen from another carrier
A person who acquired pathogen from patient
A patient who becomes a carrier

questions.text: Paradoxical carrier is defined as-
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Paradoxical carrier: This term refers to an individual who becomes a carrier of a pathogen after acquiring it from another carrier.

It is termed "paradoxical" because the carrier status is unexpected or paradoxical given the usual understanding of how individuals acquire infections.

Explanation to why other options are not correct:

A person who sheds pathogens during the incubation period (Option A): This describes a different concept, where an individual sheds the pathogen during the incubation period of the disease, before symptoms appear. It doesn't specifically refer to a carrier acquiring the pathogen from another carrier.

A person who acquired the pathogen from a patient (Option C): While this option describes the acquisition of the pathogen from a patient, it doesn't specify that the individual became a carrier as a result. Also, the term "paradoxical carrier" specifically implies acquisition from another carrier.

A patient who becomes a carrier (Option D): This option is close to the correct definition but lacks the specificity of acquiring the pathogen from another carrier. It could refer to any patient who becomes a carrier, whether they acquired the pathogen from another carrier or from a non-carrier source.
